abstract.text: No overview available.
Apply conic gradient to item(s). Provide the start
and end colors, and optionally the “anchor” point around
which the conic gradient pivots and the “sweep” point
upon which it sweeps the gradient around from start
to end color (back at the beginning) going in a clockwise
direction.
Add row layers to item(s) and mutate them via closure.
See tiles() method for more documentation.
Create a single tile “canvas” with closure of abitrary content.
The mutator passed to the closure will contain the tile/canvas
carry the same options/deviation as the current mutator.
Mask the queried item(s) with an alpha mask composed of
any combination of sub-mask items added to the mask layer.
Add or edit a tileboard using a Tileboard specification
(or nil to alter existing tileboard e.g. via
closure).
Change the background color and background alpha.
Apply corners to queried item(s).
(aka “cutout/see-through”) the queried item(s)
with a 100% opacity alpha mask composed of any combination
of sub-mask items added to the mask layer.
Apply vertical gradient to item(s) providing
the start and end colors.
See gradient() method for more options.
If item also has corners, make sure gradient is
applied
corners are set so that gradient
includes corners.
Provide “inverted:true” to go opposite.
Provide Affine transform to affect offset, scale,
and/or rotation of the gradient in relation to
(separate from) the object it is applied to.
the queried item(s) with a 100% opacity alpha mask
that covers the entire area of the item(s) with optional
outset values, respecting corners by default.
the queried item(s) with a 100% opacity alpha mask
composed of any combination of sub-mask items added to the
mask layer.
Add tile layers to item(s) and mutate them via closure.
Provide optional
. The variation index will
be provided to the closure in order to help determine how
the tile should be decorated. Specify
of tiles on
either axis, both axes or no axes to get specific number of
tiles with size relative to parent. Specify number of tiles
on a
to provide rows or columns (vs cells). If
there is more than 1 variation, adjust number of tiles to
improve “checkered” effect if that is your goal. Apply
on either axis as a positive or negative value, to create gaps
between tiles or for tiles to overlap (which is effective
if tiles have alpha values). Apply
to make tiles
an absolute sizing (per axis). This will implicitly override
the “number” parameter for the given axis and will cause the
creation of additional tiles beyond the bottom/right side.
Specify
boolean if tiles should be masked per the size
of the matrix, respecting rounded corners. The default behavior
(if not specifying mask boolean) is to automatically apply the
mask to shape/text layers, but not to plain layers.
Provide
to expand the tile matrix from any side
(or use negative values to contract the matrix).
Since this will expand/contract the area within which the tiles
will be computed, size/spacing may be altered accordingly.
Provide affine transform that will affect the entire tile
matrix. To transform individually tiles, do so in the closure.
Provide a
to mutate the tiles using the full
Mutator API. The closure will be provided with the mutator
of a tile and the variation index to help determine how
the tile should be decorated. The mutator passed to the closure
will contain the same options/deviation as the current mutator.
Randomization (via .mutate(.random, deviation:..)) affects
absolute size, offset values and is passed down (with other
Mutator options) to the visitor closure. To randomize variation
index, provide index randomization in the closure. Example:
.tiles { tile, _ in
switch (1…3).random {
case 1 : ..
etc ..
Performance tip: Prefer setting tiles
resizing item(s) or
setting corner radius/mask to avoid unnecessarily refreshing the tiles.
See also “tileboard” API for high performance alternative to tiles.
See Mutator.embedMaskedView() which supports masked hierarchies
if the desire is to transform/animate tiles within a masked area.
Apply a graduated conic mask to the item(s) so that
the item content gradually fades from one side of the
cone to the other. Specify where the cone “anchor” is
and the cone “sweep” (e.g. .center and .bottom, etc).
Specify “join” to control how the cone joins.
Use “phase” to control when the mask starts fading.
Use “inverted” to switch the direction of visibility.
Provide “outset” values to grow the mask outside the items.
Optionally pass “corners” to specify corner radius
and which corners for the mask be restricted to. Default
is 0.0 radius. Pass “nil” to inherit containing corners.
NOTE: specifying a reference item on the query will cause the
mask geometry (+ outset) to be relative to the reference item.
Add colored columns to the item(s).
See coloredTiles() method for more documentation.
Add or edit stripeboard on item(s).
A stripeboard is a single shape composed of alternating
solid and transparent rows (i.e. “stripes”).
See checkerboard() method for more documentation.
Apply corner
to queried item(s) – default: 12.0 points.
Apply borders to the queried item(s) with given width,
color and optional dash pattern.
Dash pattern is expressible using array,
.border(1.0, dashPattern:[10.0,5.0])
Specifying line phase and/or line cap, example:
To create a dash pattern of 10 points with 5 point gaps,
20 point phase (where the pattern starts on the path) and
a line cap of “round”:
.border(1.0, dash:DashPattern([10,5], phase:20, lineCap:.round))
Optionally “outset” or “inset” the border relative to rectangular
object it is bordering, using “edgeOffst” – with negative values
causing outset and positive values causing inset. If rounded corners
exist, the offset border will be concentric relative to the corners.
For advanced border creation, use compositeBorder() with closure.
Provide Affine transform to affect offset, scale,
and/or rotation of the border in relation to
(separate from) the object the border is on.
Apply conic gradient to item(s). Provide the start
and end colors, and optionally the “anchor” point around
which the conic gradient pivots and the “sweep” point
upon which it sweeps the gradient around from start
to end color (back at the beginning).
Default anchor is center and sweep is bottom trailing.
Anchor/sweep are specified as Quadrantals but can also
be relative values (0.0-1.0) in an array: e.g. [0.5, 1.0].
Colors are applied clockwise from the beginning ray
(from anchor to sweep points).
Provide “join” value to control how the end and start
colors meet together. Default join “none” provides a high
contrast joining, join “continuous” starts and ends
with the “start” color for no visible join, and join
“soft(degree:)” provides a soft graduation (by degree)
between the end and start colors.
Use “gradient()” method for more control over conic gradients.
Provide Affine transform to affect offset, scale,
and/or rotation of the gradient in relation to
(separate from) the object it is applied to.
Apply a graduated mask to the item(s) so that
the item content (including background color)
gradually fade out from leading to trailing.
Optionally adjust the “start”/“end” (floats) to inset
the mask (e.g. “startPoint:0.1”). Specify “doubleSided”
for the mask visibility to start in the center and go
out toward non-visibility on the leading and trailing sides.
Use “phase” to control when the mask starts fading, e.g.:
“.early” starts fading quickly and “.late” later.
Provide any decimal value between 0.0 and 1.0 with 0.5
being the default. Use “inverted” to switch from trailing
to leading (or outside to inside if doubleSided).
To ensure mask includes content that spills outside of
bounds, provide “outset” values.
Optionally pass “corners” to specify corner radius
and which corners for the mask be restricted to. Default
is 0.0 radius. Pass “nil” to inherit containing corners.
Example:
.horizontalGradientMask(
start       : 0.1,
doubleSided : true,
phase       : .early,
inverted    : true, // fade trailing to leading
outset      : [.leading:50.0]
NOTE: specifying a reference item on the query will cause the
mask geometry (+ outset) to be relative to the reference item.
Apply radial gradient to item(s) providing the
center and parimeter colors.
Provide phase to move median color value
toward parimeter (late) or center (early).
See gradient() method for more options.
If item also has corners, make sure gradient is
applied
corners are set so that gradient
includes corners.
Provide “inverted:true” to reverse direction of
of colors from corners to center.
Provide Affine transform to affect offset, scale,
and/or rotation of the gradient in relation to
(separate from) the object it is applied to.
Apply composite borders to queried item(s). In addition to what
regular borders support, “composite borders” support gradients,
outlines, offset, scaling, rotation, edge offsets and nesting (multiple borders).
To offset/scale/rotate the entire composed border (vs individual
offset/scale/rotate) pass an Affine transform. Nested borders may
override offset/scale/rotate individually as needed. This is slightly
different than how transforms usually work, in that offset/scale/rotate
used in the build closure are overrides of the global transform rather than additive.
NOTE: Border is drawn with it’s center on the edge of the parent.
Use “edgeOffset” to move border within edge of parent, if desired.
Example:
.compositeBorder(with:Affine(offset:10, rotate:-15)) {
$0.gradient = VerticalGradient(..)
$0.outline {
$0.width = 1.0
$0.color = ..
$0.add {
$0.width = 5.0
$0.color = ..
$0.offset = 0.0
// reset above offset for this nested border
// without affecting the rotation.
Apply gradient to item(s).
Provide Affine transform to affect offset, scale,
and/or rotation of the gradient in relation to
(and separate from) the object it is applied to.
Add column layers to item(s) and mutate them via closure.
See tiles() method for more documentation.
Wrapper for mutation of an item’s size, position, etc.
Add colored tiles to the item(s). Provide any number
of tile
(at desired alpha) – tiles will
be displayed with alternating colors. Specify
of tiles on either axis, both axes or no axes to get
specific number of tiles with size relative to parent.
Specify number of tiles on a
to provide
rows or columns (vs cells). If there is more than 1
color, adjust number of tiles to improve “checkered”
effect if that is your goal. Apply
on either
axis as a positive or negative value, to create gaps
between tiles or for tiles to overlap (which is effective
if colors have alpha values). Apply
to make tiles
an absolute sizing (per axis). This will implicitly override
the “number” parameter for the given axis and will cause the
creation of additional tiles beyond the bottom/right side.
Specify
boolean if tiles should be masked per the size
of the matrix, respecting rounded corners. The default behavior
(if not specifying mask boolean) is to automatically apply the
mask to shape layers, but not to plain layers.
Provide
to expand the tile matrix from any side
(or use negative values to contract the matrix).
Since this will expand/contract the area within which the tiles
will be computed, size/spacing may be altered accordingly.
Randomization affects absolute size or offset values only.
Provided colors may be randomized via Mutator “.randomColor”
option and deviation (for hue rotation).
Performance tip: Prefer setting tiles
resizing item(s) or
setting corner radius/mask to avoid unnecessarily refreshing the tiles.
See Mutator.embedMaskedView() which supports masked hierarchies
if the desire is to transform/animate tiles within a masked area.
Apply gradient to item(s) providing start and
end points for the gradient (between 0,0 and 1,1)
or express this as a layout position (e.g.
.topLeading or .bottom), an array of colors and
an array of respective stops for the colors between
See also convenience vertical/horizontal methods.
If item also has corners, make sure gradient is
applied
corners are set so that gradient
includes corners.
Provide Affine transform to affect offset, scale,
and/or rotation of the gradient in relation to
(and separate from) the object it is applied to.
Optionally specify “radial” or “conic” style gradients.
Apply horizontal gradient to item(s) providing
the start and end colors.
See gradient() method for more options.
If item also has corners, make sure gradient is
applied
corners are set so that gradient
includes corners.
Respects layout direction by default. (gradient
will go opposite on right-to-left layouts)
Provide “inverted:true” to go opposite.
Provide Affine transform to affect offset, scale,
and/or rotation of the gradient in relation to
(separate from) the object it is applied to.
Add performant checkerboard to item(s).
A checkerboard is a single shape composed of alternating
solid and transparent “checkers” (square tiles or shapes).
Apply dashed borders to the queried item(s) with given width,
color and dash pattern style. Use the main border() operator
if provided styles do not suit your needs.
Optionally “outset” or “inset” the border relative to rectangular
object it is bordering, using “edgeOffst” – with negative values
causing outset and positive values causing inset. If rounded corners
exist, the offset border will be concentric relative to the corners.
Provide Affine transform to affect offset, scale,
and/or rotation of the border in relation to
(separate from) the object the border is on.
Apply a graduated radial mask to the item(s) so that
the item content (including background color)
gradually fade out from center to parimeter.
Optionally adjust the “center”/“radius” (floats).
Center can be expressed as a Layout Position such as
“.center”, “.top”, “bottomTrailing”, etc or as a
pair of relative values such as [0.5, 0.2].
Radius is expressed as a single value (0.5) or for
both axes ([0.5, 0.1]). Radius is capped at the max
allowable for the rectangular area the radial mask
occupies (between relative size of 0.0 and 1.0),
with the proportions of the radius being constrained
to that of the rectangular area - e.g. [0.5,0.5] within
a rectangle of aspect ratio 1 (width) : 1.5 (height) will
will stretch to be a vertical oval shape, and not a
circular shape as you might expect. Adjust the radius
(on the relevant axis) to achieve a more or less
circular or ovular shape.
NOTE: Animating radial masks will provide inconsistent
results when the center value must pass through a parimeter
value, in which case the mask will need to flip in transit
and may also cause animation artifacts.
Use “phase” to control when the mask starts fading, e.g.:
“.early” starts fading (from center) and “.late” later.
Provide any decimal value between 0.0 and 1.0 with 0.5
being the default.
Use “inverted” to switch mask from parimeter to center.
(Parameter “doubleSided” is provided for symmetry with
other gradient mask types, but is of limited usefulness
with radial masks.)
To ensure mask includes content that spills outside of
bounds, provide “outset” values.
Optionally pass “corners” to specify corner radius
and which corners for the mask be restricted to. Default
is 0.0 radius. Pass “nil” to inherit containing corners.
Example:
.radialGradientMask(
center      : .center,
radius      : 0.5,
phase       : .early,
inverted    : true, // fade parimeter to center
outset      : [.leading:50.0]
NOTE: specifying a reference item on the query will cause the
mask geometry (+ outset) to be relative to the reference item.
Apply diagonal gradient (top-left to bottom-right)
to item(s) providing the start and end colors.
See gradient() method for more options.
If item also has corners, make sure gradient is
applied
corners are set so that gradient
includes corners.
Respects layout direction by default. (gradient
will go opposite on right-to-left layouts).
Provide “inverted:true” to get a cross-diagonal
(top-right to bottom-left (on left-right-layout)).
Provide Affine transform to affect offset, scale,
and/or rotation of the gradient in relation to
(separate from) the object it is applied to.
Add or edit pinboard on item(s).
A pinboard is a single shape composed of alternating
solid and transparent columns (i.e. “pins”).
See checkerboard() method for more documentation.
Apply a graduated mask to the item(s) so that
the item content (including background color)
gradually fade out from top to bottom.
Optionally adjust the “start”/“end” (floats) to inset
the mask (e.g. “startPoint:0.1”). Specify “doubleSided”
for the mask visibility to start in the center and go
out toward non-visibility on the top and bottom sides.
Use “phase” to control when the mask starts fading, e.g.:
“.early” starts fading quickly and “.late” later.
Provide any decimal value between 0.0 and 1.0 with 0.5
being the default. Use “inverted” to switch from bottom
to top (or outside to inside if doubleSided).
To ensure mask includes content that spills outside of
bounds, provide “outset” values.
Optionally pass “corners” to specify corner radius
and which corners for the mask be restricted to. Default
is 0.0 radius. Pass “nil” to inherit containing corners.
Example:
.verticalGradientMask(
start       : 0.1,
doubleSided : true,
phase       : .early,
inverted    : true, // fade bottom to top
outset      : [.leading:50.0]
NOTE: specifying a reference item on the query will cause the
mask geometry (+ outset) to be relative to the reference item.
Add colored columns to the item(s).
See coloredTiles() method for more documentation.
Apply a gradient mask to the item(s) so that
the item content (including background color)
gradually fade out, in whatever direction you
specify using start/end points to specify direction
of graduation. Normally, the mask starts on one side
with full visibility and graduates to the other side
at no visibility. Specify “doubleSided” for the mask
visibility to start in the center and go out toward
non-visibility on the perpendicular sides. Use “phase”
to control when the mask starts fading, e.g.: “.early”
starts fading quickly and “.late” later. Provide any
decimal value between 0.0 and 1.0, with 0.5 being the
default. Use “inverted” to invert the direction of the
graduated mask. To ensure mask includes content that
spills outside of bounds, provide “outset” values.
Optionally pass “corners” to specify corner radius
and which corners for the mask be restricted to. Default
is 0.0 radius. Pass “nil” to inherit containing corners.
Example:
.gradientMask(
doubleSided: true,
phase      : .early,
inverted   : false
outset     : [.leading:50.0]
See also convenience API for horizontal/vertical masks.
NOTE: specifying a reference item on the query will cause the
mask geometry (+ outset) to be relative to the reference item.
